member.name: WS_MESSAGE_PROPERTY_ID
member.summary: Each message property is of type , is identified by an ID, and has an associated value.

summary.para: This property is used with .
The accompanying value member of the structure is the current of the message.
This property is available in all message states.
This property is used with .

The accompanying value member of the structure is the WS_HEAP of the message. The heap is owned by the message. A user of a message is free to make additional allocations within this heap. Allocations within the heap are freed when a message is reset/freed.
The user of the returned heap should not call on the heap. This will result in undefined behavior.
The message object will not use the heap object unless one of the message APIs is invoked.
This property is available in all message states except . Using the heap of an empty message will result in undefined behavior.
This property is used with .
The accompanying value member of the structure is the of the message.
When creating a message using , the envelope version is specified as an explicit parameter (instead of as a property).
This property may be specified when message properties are specified using the structure.
This property is available in all message states except .
This property is used with .
The accompanying value member of the structure is the of the message.
When creating a message using , the addressing version is specified as an explicit parameter (instead of as a property).
This property may be specified when message properties are specified using the structure.
This property is available in all message states except .
This property is used with .
The accompanying value member of the structure is a WS_XML_BUFFER that holds the headers of the message (as well as the envelope and body elements).
This buffer is valid until the message is reset/freed.
This property is available in all message states except .
This property is used with .

The accompanying value member of the structure is the of the header element within the header buffer (the element that contains all the message headers as children). The header buffer itself can be obtained using .

An application can use the returned as a starting point when reading or writing headers manually (when not using ,, or ).
For example, the position can be passed to or to position an XML Reader or XML Writer within the WS_XML_BUFFER containing the headers. Additionally, or can be used to move relative to the position that was set.

When the headers of a message are read (via or, a header element is automatically added to the header buffer if one is not present in the message being read. When a message is initialized (via ), a header element is added automatically to the message.
This property is available in all message states except .
The header position is valid until the message is reset or freed.
This property is used with .
The accompanying value member of the structure is a WS_XML_READER that can be used to read the body of the message.
The reader is owned by the message object, and is valid only until either or are called.
This property is only available when the message is in state.
This property is used with .
The accompanying value member of the structure is a WS_XML_WRITER that can be used to write the body of the message.
This property is only available when the message is in state.
The writer is owned by the message object, and is valid only until either or are called.
This property is used with .
The accompanying value member of the structure is a BOOL indicating whether the message has been addressed.
When a message is created or reset, this property is set to FALSE.
When a message is read ( or, then this property is set to TRUE.
This property is available in all message states except .
See for more information.
This property is used with to specify the properties of the WS_HEAP associated with the message.
The accompanying value member of the structure is of type .
The heap is used to buffer the headers of the message.
The following heap properties may be specified:
This property is used with to specify properties that apply to XML Readers that are used with the message.
These XML Reader properties are used by the message object when reading headers. In addition, channels use these properties for the readers that they create to read messages.
The accompanying value member of the structure is of type .
The following properties may be specified:
This property is used with to specify the properties of the XML Writers that are used with the message.
These XML Writer properties are used by the message object when writing headers. In addition, channels use these properties for the writers that they create to write messages.
The accompanying value member of the structure is of type .
The following properties may be specified:
This property is used with or to indicate whether a message contains a fault.
The accompanying value member of the structure is a BOOL.

When a message is read ( or ), this property is set according to whether the first element of the body is a fault element. An application can test this property as a way of deciding whether to read the body as a fault. To read the body as a fault, use with to obtain a .

When a message is written ( or ) this property can be used to indicate whether or not the application will write a fault in the body. Some channels will use this information in order to determine how to send the message. For example, HTTP will send a 500 status code for faults instead of 200.

When a message is initialized using with, the property is set to TRUE.
For other WS_MESSAGE_INITIALIZATION values, the property is set to FALSE.
This property is available in all message states except .
This property is used with to specify the maximum number of headers that will be allowed when processing the message headers.
The accompanying value member of the structure is a ULONG.
The purpose of this limit is to put an upper bound on the number of iterations spent scanning for a header.
Since an application can directly modify the contents of the header buffer, this limit is not enforced in all cases. It is only enforced when one of the header access APIs are used (, ,, or ).
The default value is 64.
This property is used with to retrieve the sender's username from a received message, if username/password based security is on, or if a custom channel has set the value.
The accompanying value member of the structure is a structure.
The returned value is good until the message is freed or reset.
A custom channel can use to set the sender's username from the message if it supports username/password based security. The function will make a copy of the value specified.
This property is available in all message states except.

This property is used with to retrieve the sender's certificate from a received message as encoded bytes, if a certificate-based security mode (such as SSL) is on, or if a custom channel has set the value.
The accompanying value member of the structure is a structure.
The returned value is good until the message is freed or reset.
A custom channel can use to set the sender's certificate from a received message if it supports a certificate-based security mode. The function will make a copy of the value specified.
This property is available in all message states except.

member.name: WS_MESSAGE_PROPERTY_ID.WS_MESSAGE_PROPERTY_TRANSPORT_SECURITY_WINDOWS_TOKEN
member.summary:
This property is used with to retrieve the Windows token representing the sender from a received message. This property is available in the following cases:
The accompanying value member of the structure is a HANDLE.
is being used.
is being used and the translation from client certificate to Windows token has been enabled at the http.sys config level.
A custom channel implementation has set the value.
The returned value is good until the message is freed or reset.
A custom channel can use to set the sender's certificate from a received message if it supports a certificate-based security mode. The function will duplicate the handle specified.
This property is available in all message states except.

summary.para: This property is used with to retrieve the Windows token representing the sender from a received message, if the is used, or if a custom channel has set the value.
The accompanying value member of the structure is a HANDLE.
The returned value is good until the message is freed or reset.
A custom channel can use to set the windows token representing the sender from a received message. The function will duplicate the handle specified.
This property is available in all message states except.
This property is used with to retrieve the Windows token representing the sender from a received message, if a message security binding such as is used, or if a custom channel has set the value.
The accompanying value member of the structure is a HANDLE.
The returned value is good until the message is freed or reset.
A custom channel can use to set the token representing the sender from a received message. The function will duplicate the handle specified.
This property is available in all message states except.
This property is used with to retrieve the SAML assertion representing the sender from a received message, if the is used on the server side, or if a custom channel has set the value.
The accompanying value member of the structure is a WS_XML_BUFFER.
The returned value is good until the message is freed or reset.
A custom channel can use to set the SAML assertion representing the sender from a received message. The function will duplicate the buffer specified.
This property is available in all message states except.
This property is used with to retrieve the secure conversation handle if the is used on the server side.
The accompanying value member of the structure is a WS_SECURITY_CONTEXT.
The returned value is good until the message is freed or reset.
This property is used with to retrieve the message's security protection level.
The accompanying value member of the structure is a value.
If the channel does not use security, or if security verification failed, the protection level is set to. Otherwise it is set to the level requested by the application.
This property may be used to determine the status of the security verification when is set to FALSE.
A custom channel can use to set the protection level of a received message.
This property is available in all message states except.
